intro: Razoumofskya douglasii subsp. laricis, commonly known as the western larch, is a coniferous tree native to western North America. It belongs to the family Pinaceae and is characterized by its deciduous needles that turn golden before falling in the fall. The tree can grow up to 40 meters tall and has a straight trunk with a broad, pyramidal crown. Its bark is thick and fissured, providing protection against fire and pests. This subspecies is adapted to cold, dry environments and is often found in mountainous regions.
